Award.AwardTitle: Examining the Persistance and Motivation of STEM Pre-Service Teachers of Color in the Sherman STEM Teacher Scholars Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support fundamental STEM education research that examines broadening participation within the STEM teacher workforce. By investigating the factors that influence undergraduate student persistence in STEM and teacher education, it has the potential to contribute new knowledge about the recruitment and retention of underrepresented minority pre-service STEM teachers. The investigator has designed a professional development plan that will support building his capacity to do explanatory sequential mixed methods research design and advanced inferential statistical analysis. Professional development activities include participating in mixed method workshops and quantitative research methodology courses. The investigator will be mentored by a team of experts in STEM education methodology and quantitative analysis. Aligning a research pilot project with professional development in STEM education research will position the investigator to contribute research findings that can inform efforts to increase representation of minorities in the STEM teacher workforce.

The goal of the research project is to understand components of the Sherman STEM Teacher Scholars program at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, that affect recruitment and retention of underrepresented minority students in STEM teacher education. Guided by social cognitive theory, the study will address three questions relevant to the study variables: (1) What major effects and interactions significantly influence underrepresented minority students to pursue teaching careers? (2) What factors propel students to persist in their STEM courses? and (3) What factors contribute to degree completion and pursuit of teaching careers? The research design employs an explanatory sequential mixed method approach that includes the collection and analysis of quantitative and qualitative data. The expected impacts include informing best practices through which pre-service STEM teacher preparation programs can increase minority representation. The project could lead to the creation of a replicable STEM teacher education model for other institutions.

This project is supported through the EHR Core Research: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research (ECR: BCSER) competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF research project explored how the Sherman STEM Teacher Scholars Program (STEP) recruits and retains students of color and what outside factors influence these students to consider STEM teaching as a career. In addition, to determine the impact of the program on STEM persistence, this project compared the Sherman Scholars Program participants to those students who were STEM majors but not a member of the Sherman Scholars Program. Secondarily, the purpose of this project was to support the development of the PI’s ability to carry out mixed-methods research. This included the PI taking statistics courses and having two quantitative mentors to help guide the quantitative aspect of this mixed-methods project.

This mixed methods study found STEP participants had higher levels of academic integration than non-STEP participants, women scored higher on persistence factors than men, and White students had a higher degree commitment than students of color. Interviews with 17 survey completers (7 STEP, 10 non-STEP) indicated that STEP provided a family atmosphere that helped students connect their coursework to their career aspirations. However, women of color in particular were subjected to stereotypes from their White classmates in their STEM courses, which impacted their degree commitment. Findings show how students of color in STEP relied on the program as a counterspace to nurture and support their persistence as STEM majors.

The analysis also included a comparison of matched non-STEP STEM major counterparts (N=54) to understand the differences in the likelihood to teach. When compared to their matched non-STEP STEM counterparts, STEP participants were significantly more likely to pursue teaching. Within group analyses of STEP participants revealed that STEP students were more likely to plan to teach if they rated teaching benefits significantly higher. Interviews with 7 STEP survey completers revealed that STEP provided an opportunity for students to connect coursework to their future careers as teachers. Similarly, STEP participants were provided space to develop meaningful relationships within the program which strengthened their desire to teach. Findings indicated that support services, as well as hands-on experiences, contribute to positive student perceptions of the program and increased interest in teaching and also signaled for some that teaching was not their career choice. 

The intellectual merit of this study is centered on the study’s potential to contribute new knowledge on the recruitment and retention of STEM pre-service teachers of color. Because of the national shortage of highly qualified STEM teachers and STEM teachers of color, this study provides new knowledge on how pre-service STEM teacher programs can better retain student of color. For example, findings suggest that participants in the Sherman Scholars have a higher sense of support to complete their STEM courses than non-STEPs who participated in this study as a comparison group. Furthermore, qualitative interviews suggested that students of color believe in their ability to become teachers because the Sherman STEM Teacher Scholars program provide them opportunities to engage in teaching experiences before they enter student teaching.

There are several broader impacts of this study. First this study will help colleges and universities understand the factors that lead students to persist as STEM majors and teacher candidates. These insights can be used by colleges and universities to develop retention and recruitment policies and practices to increase the number of students of color majoring in STEM disciplines and teacher education. Second, understanding the factors that influence pre-service teachers of color to pursue a career in teaching can lead to program efforts to recruit students at the K-12 level. Researching the Sherman STEM Teacher Scholars program will provide insights into program components that best support students of color seeking to become STEM educators. Third, this research can lead to the creation of a STEM pre-service teacher education model that can be replicated at other institutions.
